title: Pheochromocytoma in MEN 2A
setup_script: “A 40-year-old man with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A presents with episodic headaches, palpitations, and paroxysmal hypertension. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “Plasma and urinary metanephrines are markedly elevated. What is your next step?”
“CT scan shows a 5 cm left adrenal mass. MRI confirms localization to the adrenal. MIBG scan is negative for extra-adrenal disease. What would you like to do next?”
“How would you optimize this patient prior to surgery?”
“The patient is started on phenoxybenzamine for 14 days. Blood pressure stabilizes but remains elevated at times. What is your next step?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident adds beta-blockade after alpha-blockade
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient’s heart rate improves. What additional preoperative measures would you recommend?”
“The patient is started on a high-sodium diet and hydration. He is scheduled for surgery. What surgical approach would you consider?”
“The patient is taken to the operating room. Please describe the key operative steps you would perform.”
“During dissection, there are significant blood pressure fluctuations. How would you manage this intraoperatively?”
“The anesthesiologist manages hypertension with short-acting vasodilators. Bleeding is controlled, and the adrenal vein is ligated. What are your next operative steps?”
“The adrenal gland is removed laparoscopically. What is your immediate postoperative management?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident monitors hemodynamics and glucose
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient has transient hypotension postoperatively, which stabilizes with fluids. Blood glucose levels are elevated. How will you continue management?”
“This patient only had unilateral adrenalectomy, and adrenal function is preserved. What additional follow-up is required?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses pathology and genetic evaluation
dynamic_flow.reply: “Pathology confirms pheochromocytoma. Genetic counseling is arranged. Family members are being screened. How would you structure long-term follow-up for this patient?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not address recurrence or surveillance
dynamic_flow.reply: “Given the patient’s MEN 2A syndrome, what is your long-term surveillance strategy?”

critical_decision_points: Correct preoperative preparation with alpha blockade and volume expansion.
Appropriate timing and choice of surgical approach.
Technical performance of adrenalectomy, including control of adrenal vein.
Recognition and management of intraoperative hemodynamic instability.
Postoperative monitoring for hypotension, glucose disturbances, and adrenal insufficiency.
Genetic counseling and long-term MEN 2A surveillance.

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing pheochromocytoma based on classic clinical features and confirming with biochemical testing. You showed good judgment by discussing appropriate preoperative alpha blockade and intraoperative collaboration with anesthesia. Communication of your management plan was structured and clear.Areas for Improvement: Further detail regarding the technical steps of adrenalectomy, particularly early adrenal vein control, would strengthen your surgical knowledge. Earlier emphasis on lifelong surveillance and family screening in MEN 2A would also improve your management.Suggested Reading Topics: - Pheochromocytoma and Paraganglioma (SCORE Curriculum) - Preoperative Management of Endocrine Tumors (ACS/ASE Review Manual) - MEN 2 Syndromes and Surveillance Guidelines (NCCN/Endocrine Society) - Operative Techniques in Adrenalectomy
